author: lightclient
content: Why is `EPOCHS_PER_ETH1_VOTING_PERIOD` `64` instead of say `1` epoch?

author: protolambda
content: Because you wouldn't want a very small set of proposers to collude and make a bad majority vote go in so quickly. Fork choice can technically avoid such events, but avoiding such situation altogether is better.

author: lightclient
content: do validators attesting to a block not check that the eth1 root is valid?

author: protolambda
content:
According to the fork choice spec:
> Eth1 data: The large ETH1_FOLLOW_DISTANCE specified in the honest validator document should ensure that state.latest_eth1_data of the canonical Ethereum 2.0 chain remains consistent with the canonical Ethereum 1.0 chain. If not, emergency manual intervention will be required.

author: protolambda
content: That distance, and a large majority vote, is what the spec describes.

author: lightclient
content: ah i see, so it's just the proposers who are voting on the canonical eth1 root -- attesters just disregard the proposers vote when running the fork choice?

author: protolambda
content: And honest validators would not be able to build on a bad majority vote, since they cannot include the claimed deposits. Such chain should stall, and get forked out. Not my design however, so I may be missing other key points

author: lightclient
content: makes sense, thanks <@!203220829473996800>  ðŸ™‚

author: sacha6557
content:
> And honest validators would not be able to build on a bad majority vote, since they cannot include the claimed deposits. 
<@!203220829473996800> why can't they include the claimed deposits?

author: protolambda
content: if there is some malicous deposit root voted in, the honest validators would simply not recognize it. And proposers are forced to include deposits in order, if we know they exist based on the previous majority vote. So such bad deposit chain should stay (almost, except rare attacker proposal) empty

author: protolambda
content: This is more of a "what if", after a hypothetical attack though. In reality I expect the follow distance and vote period to do its work. And if not, it's a special thing, we fork it out manually, and increase the voting period until we decide on a better solution.
